utterances: And that's something that we might have predicted because we knew that those groups were at risk for having a false negative mammogram.
And we should distinguish between digital and computer-assisted.
Definitely.
Computer-assisted is where a computer helps read the traditional film X-ray, is that correct?
That's right.

And I think the recent study in computer-aided detection confused some of our patients who came in and said, well, I know that you just have digital but I just read an article that said that it actually was worse than the other methods.
Computer-aided detection is a software program than can be applied to either a digitally acquired or a digitized mammogram.
But that is to guide the radiologist to look at certain areas that this software program has marked as potentially suspicious for malignancy.
Let's hear from Judy(ph) in Santa Barbara.
Judy, welcome to the show.
Just one moment, please.
Judy, you're on the air.
I think Judy might have put us on hold.
So this - just to clarify, the study about computer-assisted mammography was about that the results from having a computer help read this film were not necessarily better.
And it seems that these are all sort of attempts to make mammograms more accurate so that there can be a better blanket recommendation about how often and how young women have them.
I mean, is there a movement to sort of build a better mammogram?
Exactly.
And one of the exciting findings in our recent history in this breast imaging research was in the New England Journal saying that, you know, for some groups of women, digital is better.
So digital mammography will find cancers better than our traditional film screen.
The more recent influence of computer-aided detection study on the performance of screening mammography said computer-aided detection is not better.
We actually found a lower overall accuracy when it was being used than when it wasn't being used.
And we have to leave it there.
Thank you, Joanne Silberner, Dr. Deborah Armstrong, and Dr. Constance Lehman.
When we come back from a short break, our own political junkie, Ken Rudin.
I'm Rebecca Roberts.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
We've already broadcast a few stories about the upcoming solar eclipse as an astronomical phenomenon.
What about the solar eclipse as a plot device?

From a 1907 silent film called ""The Eclipse: The Courtship Of Sun And Moon"" to more modern films like ""Dolores Claiborne"" and ""Apocalypto,"" solar eclipses mark moments of major change for characters.
NPR's Glen Weldon tells us what happens in some movies when darkness descends in the middle of the day.
For filmmakers, solar eclipses make a handy visual shorthand, a way to signal to the audience that stuff's about to get weird.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS"")
(As Seymour Krelborn) He didn't have anything unusual there...
Because when you can't even count on something as basic as the sun shining when it's supposed to, what can you count on?
In the 1986 musical ""Little Shop Of Horrors,"" Rick Moranis' character, Seymour, is minding his own business when...
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS"")
(As Seymour Krelborn) When suddenly, and without warning, there was this...
(As characters, singing) Total eclipse of the sun.
In this case, an eclipse is the thing that kicks off the movie by announcing the arrival of an evil man-eating flytrap from outer space.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS"")
(As Seymour Krelborn) And when the light came back this weird plant was just sitting there.
(As characters, singing) Oopsie-do (ph).
But a solar eclipse can also make for a snazzy dramatic climax, like in the 1949 Bing Crosby vehicle ""A Connecticut Yankee In King Arthur's Court,"" based on the Mark Twain novel.
Crosby goes back in time to Camelot and gets sentenced to be executed.
But he knows, thanks to his handy 1949 almanac, that an eclipse is imminent, so he pretends to be a sorcerer and issues a dire and timely threat.

(As Hank Martin) Now, with a few well-chosen words, I shall blot out the sun forever.

Punxsutawney, Pa.
The sky goes dependably dark and the crowd buys it.
I mean, they really buy it.

Save us.

Well, tell me what it was like on Tuesday.
What was the...

Well, anyone who has voted in the Democratic primary in Texas, either during the early period of voting, that 10-day early period of voting or on primary day of March 4th, is entitled to come back to their individual polling precinct that evening to engage in what we call a precinct convention.
How do these caucuses work?
The people who voted in the primary show up and then what happens?
Well, they show up.
There's an individual there, probably the precinct chair, who will call the precinct convention to order.
And at that point, the warms bodies who were there will sign in by presidential preference.

And each of those precincts will have a certain number of delegates and alternates that they elect the next level of conventions either the senatorial district convention or county convention that happens on March 29th.
Why have a two-tiered system like this, Mr. Molberg?

Well, when we put this in effect roughly after 1972 - it's the genesis of the it, because Texas was a caucus state in 1972 - it was to not only give the voters, generally, of the state a say in the national delegate selection process but it was to preserve, on the other hand, through the caucus process the role of the activists - those people who are really engaged in - would go the extra mile.
Ken Molberg, thanks very much for being with us.
Thank you.
That's Ken Molberg of the Texas State Democratic Executive Committees speaking with us from Dallas.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Jacki Lyden.
Debbie Elliott is away.
Turks went to the polls for a parliamentary election today and reelected Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

After four and a half years in power, his AK Party has once again won a majority of seats in parliament despite a campaign by opposition candidates who accused Erdogan of trying to change the strict secular system in this overwhelmingly Muslim country.
